description: From Middle English stellifien (“to make into a star; glorify, deify”), from Middle French stellifier, from Medieval Latin stellificāre, itself from Latin stella (“star”) + faciō (“make, do”).

verbs.description: stellify (third-person singular simple present stellifies, present participle stellifying, simple past and past participle stellified)

entries.meaning: (transitive, mythology) To transform from an earthly body into a celestial body; to place in the sky as such
examples: In Classical mythology, being stellified was about the greatest posthumous honor for a mortal.

entries.meaning: (transitive, astronomy) To turn into a star.
examples: An alternative way to stellify the planet may be to not collapse Jupiter, but instead to introduce a collapsed object into its core.
